Award.AwardTitle: Origin of the Electric Field-induced Strain in Lead-free Piezoelectric Ceramics
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Piezoelectric materials change their dimensions when subjected to electric fields, consequently their applications range from gas igniters, speakerphones, to medical ultrasonic imaging systems. In current commercial piezoelectric devices these materials contain ~60 wt.% of lead. Due to the toxicity of lead, recent legislation in many countries restricts its use. This project aims to uncover the fundamental mechanism of the piezoelectric deformation in lead-free ceramics. The research findings will ultimately lead to the production of ceramics that will replace lead-containing piezoelectric materials. Therefore, a significant impact on health and the environment is anticipated. In addition to getting graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups involved, this project will also directly benefit the K-12 education in local schools in Ames, Iowa through the lectures on piezoelectric devices to the Science Olympiad (http://soinc.org/) team students.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The environmental concerns about lead in Pb(Zr1-xTix)O3 (PZT) have currently stimulated extensive worldwide researches on the development of lead-free piezoelectric ceramics. Previous researchers suggest that the two best systems, ceramics based on (K0.5Na0.5)NbO3 and those based on (Bi0.47Na0.47Ba0.06)TiO3, have completely different piezoelectric deformation mechanisms from those in PZT. Limited evidence indicates that the strain from the electric field-induced phase transition becomes significant. With the PI's unique in situ transmission electron microscopy technique, this project seeks to uncover the origin of the strain that develops under applied electric fields in these lead-free ceramics. Integrated with the experimental work, computational modeling based on density functional theory methods is also planned. The outcome of this project is expected to provide critical guidelines in the development of new lead-free compositions with high and yet temperature-stable piezoelectric properties. This project is designed to have a broad impact on graduate and undergraduate materials science education. Undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, will be integrated into research at Iowa State University through various educational programs. In addition, through existing connections with the Ames Middle School science teachers, the PI plans to give lectures on piezoelectric devices and demonstrate the piezoelectric effect to the Ames Middle School Science Olympiad team students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.

Piezoelectric materials change their dimensions when subjected to electric fields, consequently their applications range from gas igniters, speakerphones, to medical ultrasonic imaging systems. In current commercial piezoelectric devices these materials contain ~60 wt.% of lead. Due to the toxicity of lead, recent legislation in many countries restricts its use. This project aims to uncover the fundamental mechanism of the piezoelectric deformation in major lead-free compositions, including the potassium sodium niobate system, the bismuth sodium titanate system, and the barium titanate system. Focusing on the polycrystalline form of these ceramics, the microstructure evolution under electric field has been investigated thoroughly and systematically with a unique in situ transmission electron microscopy technique. New phases and new phase transitions have been identified, and their impacts on piezoelectric properties have been elucidated. The results are reported in 19 articles in prestigious technical journals, including Physical Review Letters and Advanced Functional Materials. These findings will help the design of new high-performance piezoelectric compositions that aim to replace the current lead-containing ceramics. Therefore, a significant impact on health and the environment is anticipated.

 

Broader Impact.

The research findings have been broadly disseminated at other research institutions and professional technical conferences, including the NSF-DMR Ceramics PI meetings. The PIs and their PhD students have delivered 25 invited and contributed talks in the course of the project. The broad impacts of this research are also demonstrated by the education and training of next generation engineers and scientists. Working on lead-free piezoelectric materials as their thesis research, three Ph.D. students have obtained their degrees. In addition, two undergraduate students, Ms. Jordan Barr and Ms. Alexandria Bruce, were financially supported by this project and trained by the co-PI on basic computational materials science. Particularly, Jordan Barr has made significant contributions to the theoretical calculations of BaTiO3 and is a co-author in one of the publications. The outreach activities in this project benefited the K-12 education in local schools in Ames, Iowa. The PI helped the Ames Middle School Science Olympiad team through mentoring team members during their preparation for competing events.
